Award.AwardTitle: Flipping the Script: Using Short Videos to Promote Learning in Introductory Geoscience Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is developing a series of short videos for self-paced, pre-class viewing in large introductory geoscience courses and testing their impact on student learning and metacognitive judgments, including the assessment of patterns of use and video characteristics that best promote learning. The videos, which focus upon geoscience-literacy concepts, are also being tested as a component of a "flipped-classroom" approach, in which some content delivery is shifted to video format, and class meetings involve greater participation in active-learning strategies. Videos and related resources to support use and assessment are being shared with the broader geoscience community by posting to the Science Education Resource Center (SERC) website and to YouTube. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its comprehensive and timely approach, well-grounded in the literature, to developing and assessing both video resources and their use in flipped classrooms. Broader impacts include the wide availability of the videos themselves, as well as the potential for associated insights from the educational research to shift pedagogical practices in introductory geoscience courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research shows that students learn best when they work collaboratively to complete learning tasks during class meetings. These active learning exercises take time in class that would normally be devoted to lecture. While lecture is an efficient way to deliver information, it is not as effective in promoting student knowledge gains as active learning. In recent years, K-12 teachers and college professors have experimented with "flipping" their classes in an effort to transfer some of course content to preclass activities and to free up time for active learning exercises. Flipped courses place some of the responsibility for learning basic content onto the students outside of class.This is often facilitated by some type of content presentation coupled with the use of required online assessments (e.g., quizzes) which ensure that students have a stake in interacting with the basic content prior to attending class. By moving some content outside of the classroom experience, this approach can provide additional time during class meetings for instructors to incorporate activities that allow students to tackle more demanding or application-based tasks in collaboration with their peers. 

Our project sought to encourage the adoption of the flipped class model in introductory college geoscience courses. We created a series of more than 30 short videos and associated quizzes that instructors could assign to their students before class meetings. The videos covered fundamental course concepts that were relatively straigthforward for students to learn on their own. We used effective multimedia design principles to ensure that our videos would support student learning. We tested a pair of videos against equivalent textbook passages and found that students learned more by watching the videos than by reading the textbook. Further, students were more confident of their learning from the video resources. Most students noted that they sought out videos to assist their learning. Students mentioned specific qualities of video design that they look for when selecting videos - shorter videos with demonstrations, animated effects, progressive illustrations, step-by-step problem solving and examples.

We then compared how students performed on common exam questions when we presented information in lecture vs. presenting it before class by video. There was no loss in student performance from using the video. That is, students learned just as much by watching a carefully designed video as they did by listening to a professor deliver the same information in class. Further, we used some of the newly free time in class to generate new learning activities that subsequently helped students perform better on selected questions on subsequent exams. 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its contribution to both improved learning and instruction. Students who use instructionally-sound videos to develop conceptual knowledge outside of class will have a more comprehensive knowledge of geoscience concepts than students who have access to traditional resources alone (e.g., textbook) and instructors will have more time in class to engage active learning exercises.

The most significant broader impact of this project was in the production of a series of short videos that others have used to customize their instruction of essential geoscience concepts. Our Geoscience Videos YouTube channel has become a valuable resource for instructors and students. We receive unsolicited postive comments about the site from colleagues at professional meetings and the number of viewers and subscribers continues to grow.  Given the availability of the site's analytics, we can track the scale of our impact through the life of the project. The total number of views of the channel has now passed 1.2 million and we have over 7,000 subscribers. Each semester we accumulate more views and subscribers. For example, during April of 2015, we had 2,100 views of videos at the site. Now, we typically get that many views in a day. Jumping forward to April, 2018, we had more than 53,000 views. Colleagues tell us that they use the videos in a variety of ways, including as pre-class work, to support in-class discussions, as post-class reviews or homework, or as supplementary learning materials.
